SUMMARY: NESTED | FIELD | CONSTR | METHOD DETAIL: FIELD | CONSTR | METHOD

net.tmachine.gpg4.gameserver
Class HTTPRequest

java.lang.Object
  net.tmachine.gpg4.gameserver.HTTPRequest
public class HTTPRequest
extends java.lang.Object

This is a simple, straightforward implementation of methods and data to represent and create HTTP requests.

It is sufficient as an example, although not recommended for production code. In most cases, you will create a new protocol class of your own anyway.

See RFC 2616 for more details

See Also:
HTTPResponse

decodeURLEncodedForm

                                             java.util.Map result)
takes a String of data encoded using "x-www-form-urlencoded" and decodes it into name, value pairs that are then placed in the provided HashMap - or returned as a new HashMap if a null HashMap is provided

getRequestLengthInBytes

public int getRequestLengthInBytes()
This method is necessary for other classes to remove ONLY the characters representing this request from a ByteBuffer...

isCompleteRequest

public static boolean isCompleteRequest(java.lang.String req)
Note: there have been some very subtle bugs in this that were race-condition sensitive; be VERY careful if you alter this method implementation

Examines the string to see if it contains AT LEAST ONE complete HTTP Request; the request MAY NOT start at the beginning (it could start anywhere) and MAY NOT finish at the last character, but it will return true IFF the request is completely contained (i.e. not fore-shortened)

stripRelativeURL

public static java.lang.String stripRelativeURL(java.lang.String url)
Useful for security later on - lets you ensure that a URL is absolute, and cannot access other parts of the directory structure

getURIHeaderNames

public java.util.Collection getURIHeaderNames()
When name/value pairs are submitted in a GET-request query-string, this method will fetch all the names

getURIHeaderValue

public java.lang.String getURIHeaderValue(java.lang.String name)
When name/value pairs are submitted in a GET-request query-string, this method will fetch the value of a name

getURIHeaderInt

public int getURIHeaderInt(java.lang.String name,
                           int defaultValue)
Convenience method for getting the value of any String from getURIHeaderValue as an int

Merely does an Integer.parseInt with some exception-catching.

Parameters:
name - passed to getURIHeaderValue
defaultValue - if the Integer.parseInt fails, this value will be returned instead

getURIHeaders

public java.util.HashMap getURIHeaders()
Clones the HashMap of URI Headers (as used in "getURIHeaderNames" and "getURIHeaderValue"; this is mainly used by things that maintain sessions, which need to repeatedly get copies of this HashMap per page (each link that will change the URI needs a new copy in order to generate the href body)

It rather obsoletes the other two methods, but they are remaining for now for backwards compatibility.

getPOSTHeaderNames

public java.util.Collection getPOSTHeaderNames()
POST headers are loosely defined here as "the names that were encoded in an application/x-url-encoded POST request"

getPOSTHeaderValue

public java.lang.String getPOSTHeaderValue(java.lang.String name)
POST headers are loosely defined here as "the names that were encoded in an application/x-url-encoded POST request"

equals

public boolean equals(java.lang.Object o)
Note: originally this merely did a case-sensitive equals on the ENTIRE raw HTTP request; a more careful equals check would compare specific headers, ignoring irrelevant ones such as "User-Agent" and "Cookie"

Most reasons for wanting a different comparison function are for specific reasons and have different needs... in these cases, java's excellent Collections hierarchy should allow use of arbitrary Comparator objects for all places where this method would be called by default, and so this equals can be overridden at runtime on a case-by-case basis where needed.

Unfortunately, it appears someone was being a bit lazy when deciding which classes should support the Comparator - only two major Collections classes allow it, when it OUGHT to be usable by all of them.

So, this method now implements an equals() check that allows maximal caching, and ignores several major HTTP headers...

hashCode

public int hashCode()
